channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Forms New Company, in Possible Attempt to Evade NY Lawsuit
item.description: The New York attorney general, Letitia James, who is suing the former president, questioned his motive for forming a new company, which will be known in the state as the Trump Organization II.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Under scrutiny by the New York attorney general, Donald J. Trump’s business created a new company in Delaware.

item.title: Trump Aide Was Seen on Security Footage Moving Boxes at Mar-a-Lago
item.description: The aide, Walt Nauta, moved the boxes from a storage room before and after the Justice Department issued a subpoena demanding the return of all classified documents held by the former president.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department had subpoenaed security camera footage from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: These ‘Mitigating’ Factors Spared the Parkland Gunman’s Life
item.description: Reasons to show a defendant mercy include extreme mental or emotional disturbance, as well as a broad consideration of “factors in the defendant’s background.”
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Amy Beth Bennett
item.media:description: Melisa McNeill, Nikolas Cruz’s lead defense attorney, during her closing argument on Tuesday.

item.title: The Social Security COLA Increase Will Ease the Sting of Inflation
item.description: The cost-of-living adjustment will be 8.7 percent next year, bringing relief to retirees and others who rely largely on the payments.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prices have remained stubbornly high over the past year, even as federal policymakers have taken aggressive measures to rein them in.

item.title: 2023 COLA Could Strain Social Security Program
item.description: The Social Security Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund could be depleted a year or two earlier than expected as a result of larger payouts.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Social Security Administration office in New York. Now that the program will be paying out more to help retirees keep up with rising prices, it will be under even more pressure to sustain itself.

item.title: 2 Officers Shot Dead in Connecticut After Being Lured by Fake 911 Call
item.description: A third officer was seriously wounded in the violence in Bristol, officials said, and a suspect also died. The police chief called it an act of “senseless violence.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Corey Kilgannon
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers salute as a body is taken from the scene of the violence in Bristol, Conn.

item.title: With Leaps and Bounds, Parkour Athletes Turn Off the Lights in Paris
item.description: As an energy crisis looms, nimble young activists are using superhero-like moves to switch off wasteful lights that stores leave on all night.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Ha, 30, left, leader of the On The Spot Parkour collective in Paris, climbs a wall to turn off a shop’s exterior lights on the Avenue des Champs-Élysées, in September.

item.title: Inside the Global Effort to Keep Perfectly Good Food Out of the Dump
item.description: Around the world, lawmakers and entrepreneurs are taking steps to tackle two of humanity’s most pressing problems: hunger and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vue Vang collected donated food from a Trader Joe’s in Fresno, Calif., where, under a new law, grocery stores are required to donate “the maximum amount of edible food that would otherwise be disposed.”

item.title: With New Crackdown, Biden Wages Global Campaign on Chinese Technology
item.description: U.S. officials pushed to choke off China’s access to critical semiconductor technology after internal debates and tough negotiations with allies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: How Hwee Young/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An effort by the Biden administration would try to use U.S. influence over global technology and supply chains to try to choke off China’s access to advanced chips and chip production tools needed to power those abilities.

item.title: F.C.C. Readies Vote on Banning New Huawei and ZTE Devices
item.description: The vote, which is expected to pass, is required by a law that President Biden signed last year.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jonathan Newton
item.media:description: Jessica Rosenworcel, the F.C.C. chairwoman, said the agency “remains committed to protecting our national security by ensuring that untrustworthy communications equipment is not authorized for use within our borders.”

item.title: Hurricane Ian’s Financial Toll Threatens Florida’s Real Estate Market
item.description: The hurricane’s record-breaking cost will make it even harder for many to get insurance, experts say — threatening home sales, mortgages and construction.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleanup in the aftermath of Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., on Oct. 5.

item.title: In Midterm TV Ad Wars, Sticker Shock Costs Republicans
item.description: The party is paying far more for TV ads than Democrats on the exact same programs. The reasons are tied to Republicans’ reliance on super PACs.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: John Locher/Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto paid far less for a 30-second television commercial during a Las Vegas Raiders game than a Republican super PAC did.

item.title: In Utah, a Trump Loyalist Sends an S.O.S. to Romney
item.description: Senator Mike Lee, in a surprisingly close race for re-election, has antagonized Mitt Romney and the state’s G.O.P. for years. His plea now? “Please, get on board.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mike Lee played a key role in trying to help Donald J. Trump subvert the 2020 election, while his fellow Republican Utah senator, Mitt Romney, was in staunch opposition.

item.title: Chaucer the Rapist? Newly Discovered Documents Suggest Not.
item.description: That the author of “The Canterbury Tales” had been accused of rape was long a staple of Chaucer studies. But scholars now suggest it was based on a misreading of court papers from 1380.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive/Getty Images
item.media:description: New documents found related to a court case involving Geoffrey Chaucer suggest that it was not a rape case, as had been previously believed.

item.title: Bob Dylan’s “The Philosophy of Modern Song”: An Excerpt
item.description: In his first collection of writing since “Chronicles: Volume One,” Dylan explores the lasting allure of great songs. Here are two excerpts from his new book.
item.media:credit: William C. Eckenberg/The New York Times
item.media:description: Bob Dylan released 39 studio albums and won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016. He is the author of the memoir “Chronicles: Volume One.”

item.title: We Are Suddenly Taking On China and Russia at the Same Time
item.description: A battle over computer chips could have more long-term global impact than the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

item.title: Ben Sasse Is Nothing if Not Thoughtful. Right?
item.description: With the junior senator from Nebraska set to become the president of the University of Florida, it’s a good moment to plow into his most recent book.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.category: Them: Why We Hate Each Other -- and How to Heal (Book)
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Elon Musk Has Some Bad Ideas for Mass Transit. We Have Solutions.
item.description: Innovation is important, but Elon Musk’s impractical transit inventions do nothing to help solve today’s problems.
item.dc:creator: Adam Kovacs and Adam Westbrook

item.title: The Jan. 6 Committee Has Been Almost Wholly Ineffective
item.description: It has set itself up as the defender of America’s democracy. It’s the wrong venue for such a mission.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Caldwell
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times

item.title: A Revealing Racist Rant in L.A.
item.description: America is getting less white. That doesn’t mean it’s becoming less racist.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

item.title: It’s Time to Accept That North Korea Has Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The threat of a Korean conflict is rising and the U.S. has few other cards to play.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Lewis
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; images by Nosyrevy and Komarov Vitaly, via Getty Images

item.title: Haiti Has Been a Plaything of Powerful Forces for Too Long
item.description: Haiti is in crisis. If the U.S. wants to help, it needs to stop meddling.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Richard Pierrin/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of Ariel Henry, Haiti’s acting prime minister, set fires in the streets of Port-au-Prince this month.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Proved Why Ron DeSantis’s Version of Climate Resilience Is a Disaster
item.description: As the sea level rises, the resilience projects Gov. Ron DeSantis touts will have to be replaced, made higher, built larger.
item.dc:creator: Craig Pittman
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: What Happened to Monkeypox?
item.description: Why cases suddenly began to decline.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Positive monkeypox samples at the Renegade Bio processing lab from August.

item.title: ‘The Decision of My Life’: Part 3
item.description: An update on N, a teenager in Afghanistan who escaped an arranged marriage to a member of the Taliban and went into hiding in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: Lynsea Garrison, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view over Kabul. Since around the time the Taliban took over Afghanistan, only 500 of the nearly 50,000 humanitarian parole cases submitted to the Department of Homeland Security have been approved.

item.title: The Flip
item.description: Why the race for Georgia’s governor has more at stake than a single elected office.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images

item.title: Tell Us: What Questions About Climate Change Can We Answer?
item.description: There is no question too basic, or too big. Your suggestions will be used to help guide the Times’s climate coverage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Cuba Gooding Jr. Will Serve No Prison Time After Plea in Sex Abuse Case
item.description: The actor pleaded guilty to a single harassment charge after being accused of groping and kissing three women. A score of similar stories emerged after his arrest.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The criminal case against Cuba Gooding Jr. is over, but two civil suits against him continue.

item.title: Sandy Hook Families Win $1 Billion From Alex Jones
item.description: The Sandy Hook families leveraged personal stories, social media analysis and the Infowars fabulist’s lack of contrition to secure a major verdict.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones faces financial ruin after a jury awarded the families who had sued him almost $1 billion, though it is unclear how much money the families will ultimately collect.

item.title: Michigan State President Samuel Stanley Jr. Resigns
item.description: Samuel Stanley Jr. is the third president to resign since 2018. He had been under fire for his handling of a Title IX case involving the dean of the business school.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Paul Sancya/Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Samuel Stanley Jr., said he had “lost confidence” in the board of trustees.

item.title: Gaming Is Booming. That’s Catnip for Cybercriminals.
item.description: Cybersecurity experts warn that threats lurk in cheat codes, microtransactions and messages from fellow players.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Popular gaming platforms like Roblox, above, are seductive to cybercriminals and vulnerable to exploitation.

item.title: Strength Training Beginners Guide: How to Make the Workout a Habit
item.description: For real this time.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Ryan Frigillana for The New York Times

item.title: Ankle Exercises to Help Strengthen and Prevent Injury
item.description: Ankle instability is often the result of nerve and ligament damage. These exercises can help get you back on, and stay on, your feet.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Izaiah Johnson for The New York Times

item.title: How to Motivate Yourself to Exercise
item.description: Bundle your incentives. Be flexible. Get some support. Here’s how to get — and stay — motivated.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Keith E. Morrison for The New York Times

item.title: Is Barefoot Weight Lifting Safe?
item.description: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
item.description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Alice Gerrard Didn’t Plan a Bluegrass Career. She Broke Its Glass Ceiling.
item.description: Six decades ago, the singer’s duo with Hazel Dickens revolutionized the genre. As their albums are reissued, she reflected on her unexpected life in folk music and what’s next.
item.dc:creator: Grayson Haver Currin
item.category: Pioneering Women of Bluegrass: The Definitive Edition (Album)
item.media:credit: Alycee Byrd for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alice Gerrard at her home in Durham, N.C., with “Shady Grove (Alice Gerrard),” a 2009 portrait by Art Rosenbaum. Hazel and Alice’s albums helped expand bluegrass’s purview, not only with personnel but also with the politics of unions, feminism and civil rights.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
